newsitem.title: USA: Leading semiconductor index rises to 0.90.
newsitem.headline: Leading semiconductor index rises to 0.90.

text.p: The semiconductor industry's leading indicator rose slightly last month, reflecting a modest increase in new orders, a trade group said Tuesday.
The Semiconductor Industry Association said the so-called book to bill ratio, which measures new orders against shipments, rose to 0.90 in August from a revised 0.86 in July.

The index means that for every $100 in shipments, semiconductor firms received $90 in new orders. An index above 1.00 normally means demand for computer chips is expanding while a ratio below one means demand is slowing.
Industry analysts had expected the ratio to be between 0.86 and 0.92. The July ratio was revised slightly upward from 0.85.

The SIA said new orders rose 0.9 percent last month to $2.84 billion from $2.82 billion in July. The gain was offset by a continuing decline in billings, which fell 3.2 percent to $3.15 billion in August from $3.26 billion in July.
Compared with last year's levels, August chip orders were off 37.8 percent and billings were down 19.9 percent. The book-to-bill ratio in August 1995 was 1.16.

The semiconductor industry has been hurt this year by a glut in computer chips, particularly in the memory market. In recent months a number of semiconductor makers have scaled back expansion plans or halted construction of new wafer plants until the market improves.

Analysts say August is usually the weakest month of the year because many manufacturers shut down for vacation. Thus, an increase in orders during August could signal the beginning of a cyclical upturn.

The last two weeks of September are when PC makers start shipping their products for the holiday season and most of them order semiconductors "just-in-time" often only days before they are scheduled for the assembly line.

The SIA said book-to-bill numbers in the other major market sectors -- Japan, Asia and Europe -- remain higher than in the North and South American market. The final worldwide book-to-bill ratio for July, the latest period available, rose to 0.95 from 0.93 in June. Japan's book-to-bill ratio exceeded 1.02 in July.
